div1.head: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Philip Showalter Hench, October 1, 1940
div1.opener:
send
3/6/41-Card,
Mile Post etc
HOWARD A. KELLY, M. D.
LIBRARY
1406 EUTAW PLACE, BALTIMORE, MD.
1 October 1940
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Regarding your letter
concerning Walter Reed matters: It arrived here while I
was away in the North country and for several weeks after
my return I was confined to the hospital and my own bed.

You are at liberty to send
copies of any of my photographs in the Walter Reed book to
Cuba or elsewhere, simply giving recognition to the source.
I did not secure anything directly from Walter Reed since
he had died before I undertook his life and work, but was in
touch with Doctor Carroll and to the best of my memory, the
pictures and associated data came to me from him. I have
a definite memory of getting them from a direct authoritative
source, that is to say, one of the little group which after
all boils itself down to Carroll. I had no personal
relations whatsoever with Agramonte. I have no negatives
AC
In to L
of the pictures. I have a clear recollection of the
statement made that the particular building so declared was
the one in which the infected clothing experiments were tried
out. This matter was proven in a building identical to that
known as the “Infected Mosquito Building” except that the latter
was divided near the middle by a permanent wire screen partition
and had good ventilation while the former was so constructed as to
exclude anything like efficient ventilation. Please inform
Mr. Moran that my information concerning the figure by the
building certainly came from the person who supplied the
photograph and is, therefore, reliable.

So many years have passed since I gathered material for
the book that I cannot positively assert where I got the
statement of Reed, said, “Gentlemen, I salute you,” but I am
sure it was not picked up out of the air.

I do not know where Reed's daughter Blossom lives, but
the last address I had for Mrs. Walter Reed is Burlington Hotel,
Vermont Avenue, Washington, D. C.

In April, 1928, Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear lived at
HOWARD A. KELLY, M. D.
LIBRARY
1406 EUTAW PLACE, BALTIMORE, MD.
60 Oakvale Avenue, Berkeley, California.
I do not know whether Doctor Carroll has any survivors.

closer.seg:
P.S. If you come this way at any time, I shall be glad to
place the somewhat abundant material before you.
